revision.text:
'''Elmo Burns Roper Jr.''' (July 31, 1900 in [[Hebron, Nebraska|Hebron]], [[Nebraska]] – April 30, 1971 in [[Redding, Connecticut|Redding]], [[Connecticut]]<!-- Britannica says he died in West Reading, PA, but the Roper Center says Redding, Connecticut; I'll go with the Roper Center -->) was a [[pollster]] known for his pioneering work in [[market research]] and [[opinion poll]]ing. In 1933, he cofounded Cherington, Wood, and Roper, a marketing research firm.<ref name=Center>[http://www.ropercenter.uconn.edu/center/elmo_bio.html Elmo Roper Biography] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091007081321/http://www.ropercenter.uconn.edu/center/elmo_bio.html |date=2009-10-07 }} at the [[Roper Center for Public Opinion Research]]</ref> When that partnership fell apart, he founded his own research company, Elmo Roper, Inc.<ref>Survey Research in the United States: Roots and Emergence 1890-1960 By Jean M. Converse, p.113ff</ref> He was hired by [[Henry Luce]] in 1935 to run surveys for ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'', continuing these surveys for 15 years. His prediction of [[Franklin Delano Roosevelt]]'s electoral victory over [[Alf Landon]] in 1936 was correct to within 0.9%; his 1940 prediction of Roosevelt's victory was correct to within 0.5%, further solidifying the reputation of Roper's techniques.<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=888&dat=19440504&id=tcMKAAAAIBAJ&sjid=yE4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=5604,8716 Odds Favor Roosevelt for Fourth Term Should He Run, Elmo Roper Predicts] - [[St. Petersburg Times]], May 4, 1944</ref> In 1940, Roosevelt hired Roper to assess public opinion of [[Lend-Lease]] prior to its implementation.<ref name=Center/> In 1942 he was hired by [[William Joseph Donovan]] to be the deputy director of the [[Office of Strategic Services]]; Roper subsequently worked with the [[Office of War Information]]. After leaving the OWI he founded the [[Roper Center for Public Opinion Research]] at the [[University of Connecticut]] in 1947.
Roper Opinion Research Company (the "Roper Poll") was later renamed Roper Starch Worldwide Company and eventually acquired by NOP World and then [[GfK]] in 2005.
==Family== His son, [[Bud Roper]], was also a pollster.<ref>[http://www.stat.cmu.edu/~fienberg/Stat36-303-03/NewspaperArticles/RoperObit-StarTribune-1-23-03.html Pioneering pollster Burns Roper dead at 77], [[Associated Press]], January 23, 2003, archived at [[Carnegie Mellon University]].</ref>
==References== <references/>
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Roper, Elmo}} [[Category:1900 births]] [[Category:1971 deaths]] [[Category:People of the Office of Strategic Services]] [[Category:American political consultants]] [[Category:Market researchers]] [[Category:Pollsters]] [[Category:20th-century mathematicians]] [[Category:People from Hebron, Nebraska]]

{{refimprove|date=May 2018}} '''Emilio Bacardi Moreau''' (1844–1922) was a Cuban industrialist, politician, and writer who managed the [[Bacardi|Bacardi Rum Company]] and served as mayor of [[Santiago de Cuba|Santiago]].
==Biography== Emilio was the son of [[Facundo Bacardi]] and his wife Amalia Moreau. His father was a businessman who in 1862 founded the Bacardi distilling company that would grow into today's international corporation. However, before finding stability in the rum business, Facundo and his young family experienced some of tragedies of the day. For instance, in 1852 a major earthquake struck Santiago and the family briefly returned to [[Spain]] to escape the ensuing epidemics of [[cholera]] (epidemics which claimed some of Emilio's siblings). Upon his return, Facundo found that the general store he had been running was looted and its customers had fled. Within a few years he was bankrupt.
In some ways, Emilio was protected from the turbulence by distance: the family's return to Cuba was completed without him, who stayed behind with a family friend in Spain. He received instruction in literary and political topics and grew to appreciate the arts and the liberal politics of the day (including abolition of slavery, criticism of organized religion, nationalism, and democracy). By the time he returned to Cuba at the age of 17, his interests lay more in political and poetic activism than business. However, as the first-born son of his father, he was given a growing and important role in the fledgling company.
Throughout the 1870s, 80's, and 90's, Emilio's dual identity as business magnate and subversive political activist grew. The rum business continued to grow under his leadership, which was made official in 1877 when Don Facundo retired and named him president of the company. At the same time, Emilio became more and more involved in Cuba's nationalistic resistance to the [[Spanish Empire]]. He was repeatedly arrested and imprisoned on suspicion of helping the rebels. These suspicions were well founded, as Emilio used his respectable business activities and connections as a cover for developing a financial network which channelled resources to the rebel guerilla army.<ref>{{cite book|author=[[Gjelten, Tom]]|title=Bacardi and the Long Fight for Cuba|publisher=Viking|year=2008|isbn=978-0-670-01978-6|pages=45–67}}</ref>
Emilio's personal life continued to develop as well: in 1876 he married Maria Lay Berlucheau, a French Cuban from Santiago. He would go on to have a number of children with her, including Emilio (Emilito), Daniel, Jose, Facundo, Maria, and Carmen. In the spring of 1885, however, she died at the age of 33, devastating Emilio and sending him into a depression from which it took months to recover. His eventual recovery coincided with the companionship of Elvira Cape, whom he married in 1887 and lived with for the rest of his life. Their four children (Marina, Lucia, Adelaida, and Amalia) further enlarged the Bacardi family.
[[File:Panteon de Emilio Bacardi y Moreau.jpg|thumb|Burial vault of Emilio Bacardi y Moreau and his wife Elvira Cape de Bacardi, located in the [[Santa Ifigenia Cemetery]], in the provinces Santiago de Cuba, Cuba.]]
The political fortunes of both Cuba and Emilio were radically altered by the [[Spanish–American War]], in which the conquering American army took over administration of the island. The American military governor of Santiago, General [[Leonard Wood]], appointed Bacardi as mayor of Santiago. In this position, Emilio worked extensively with the American military administration, and the relationship between him and General Wood warmed to the level of friendship, tempered by their complicated political relationship.<ref>{{cite book|author=Gjelten, Tom|title=Bacardi and the Long Fight for Cuba|publisher=Viking|year=2008|isbn=978-0-670-01978-6|page=85}}</ref> As mayor, he was generally recognized as a competent and effective manager, succeeding on extending services and practicing good government under the military administration and later the new Cuban republic. His reputation for honesty and public service distinguished him from many of the would-be leaders who arose in the post-independence political scramble, and he eventually ran for and won a seat in the national senate in 1906.
==References== {{reflist}} {{refbegin}} {{refend}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bacardi, Emilio}} [[Category:People from Santiago de Cuba]] [[Category:Cuban people of French descent]] [[Category:Cuban people of Catalan descent]] [[Category:Cuban businesspeople]] [[Category:1844 births]] [[Category:1922 deaths]] [[Category:Bacardi]]

'''Fabrizio Freda''' (born 31 August 1957 in [[Naples]]) is an Italian business executive.
==Biography== He was born in [[Naples]] and graduated from [[University of Naples Federico II]] in March 1981.
==Career== He was appointed president and chief executive officer of [[Estée Lauder Companies|The Estée Lauder Companies Inc.]] on July 1, 2009,<ref name="A Letter from Our President and CEO ">{{cite web | url=http://investors.elcompanies.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=109458&p=irol-govLetterCEO | title=A Letter from Our President and CEO | publisher=Estée Lauder Cos. Inc | accessdate=7 February 2014 | author=Freda, Fabrizio}}</ref><ref>[http://www.elcompanies.com/the_company/fabrizio_freda.php Fabrizio Freda profile on Estée Lauder Companies website]</ref> succeeding [[William P. Lauder]]. He had joined the company in March 2008, when he was appointed President and Chief Operating Officer.
He was previously President of [[Procter & Gamble]]'s Global Snacks division. Freda joined P&G in 1982 and spent 10 years in the health and beauty division.
His total calculated compensation in 2016 as Chief Executive Officer, President and Director at [[Estée Lauder Companies|The Estée Lauder Companies Inc.]] was $48,369,401.<ref name="Executive profile">{{cite web | url=http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:TsN_jenkMxQJ:www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp%3FpersonId%3D2989244%26capId%3D207221%26previousCapId%3D%26previousTitle%3D+&cd=2&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=us | title=Estee Lauder Companies | publisher=Bloomberg | accessdate=11 Jul 2017 | author=Bloomberg}}</ref>
He currently works directly with SVP, Israel Assa, on business operations.<ref>https://www.dfnionline.com/product-news/cosmetics/israel-assa-joins-estee-lauder-companies-senior-capacity-20-06-2016/</ref><ref>https://www.moodiedavittreport.com/israel-assa-promoted-to-key-new-travel-retail-leadership-role-at-the-estee-lauder-companies/</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Freda, Fabrizio}} [[Category:Italian businesspeople]] [[Category:1957 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Estée Lauder Companies]]

revision.comment: removed grandparent category of [[Category:Ambassadors of the Republic of Florence]]
revision.text:
'''Felice di Michele Brancacci''' (born 1382 - fl. 15th century) was a [[Florence|Florentine]] [[silk]] merchant, best known for commissioning the decoration of the [[Brancacci Chapel]]. The nephew and heir of [[Piero di Piuvichese Brancacci]], he was involved in [[Mediterranean]] silk trade, and also acted as a diplomat.
== Biography ==
Felice is known to have won a [[Jousting|joust]] held to celebrate Florence's submission of [[Pisa]] in 1406. He acted as a diplomat for the Florentine Republic, and visited the court of the [[Sultan of Egypt]] in 1422.<ref name="S6">{{cite book | first = Ken | last = Shulman | authorlink = | title = Anatomy of a Restoration: The Brancacci Chapel | edition = | publisher = Walker | location = New York | year = 1991 | page= 6 | isbn = 0-8027-1121-9 | url = }}</ref> He was also a member of the city's Board of Maritime Consuls.<ref>{{cite book | first = U. & O. Casazza | last = Baldini | authorlink = | title = The Brancacci Chapel Frescoes | edition = | publisher = Thames and Hudson | location = London | year = 1992 | page= 39 | isbn = 0-8109-3120-6 | url = }}</ref> As a result of the decline in the wool trade, Brancacci's wealth as a silk merchant increased rapidly.<ref name="S6"/> In May 1431 he married Lena, daughter of [[Palla Strozzi]], a union that put him at the centre of Florentine politics.<ref>{{cite book | first = Jonathan | last = Davies | authorlink = | title = Florence and its University during the Early Renaissance | edition = | publisher = Brill | location = Leiden | year = 1998 | pages= 77–9 | isbn = 90-04-11003-8 | url = }}</ref> In 1433, a number of the most powerful families of the city – including the Strozzis – had driven the family of [[Cosimo de Medici]] into exile. When the Medicis returned in triumph the next year, Brancacci was among those expelled as an enemy of the Republic, in spite of his attempts to stay out of active political ploys.<ref>Shulman, p. 9.</ref>
== The Brancacci Chapel == {{Main|Brancacci Chapel}} Sometime after 1423 and before 1425 Brancacci supposedly commissioned the painter Masaccio to decorate the walls of the Brancacci chapel left by his uncle.<ref name="S6"/> The subject was the life of Saint Peter, the [[Saint's name|name-saint]] of the founder, and the patron saint of the Brancacci family. The choice also reflected support for the [[Rome|Roman]] [[pope|papacy]] during the [[Western Schism|Great Schism]].<ref name="S6"/> Masolino was later joined by the younger artist Tommaso Cassai, or [[Masaccio]]. Masaccio's contributions to the [[fresco]]es – including ''[[The Tribute Money (Masaccio)|The Tribute Money]]'' – are considered the most important, and central to the development of [[renaissance]] art.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0PAL/is_511_160/ai_n9769989/pg_1 | title = St Peter and the Brancacci chapel | publisher = [[Apollo (magazine)|Apollo]] | author = Margaret Finch | date = September 2004 | accessdate = 2008-02-12}}</ref> Both artists left before the work was completed, however, in 1427 or 28.<ref>Schulman, p. 7-10.</ref> It was not until the 1480s, when the Brancaccis were allowed to return from exile, that the work was finished, by [[Filippino Lippi]].<ref>{{cite book | first = Jules | last = Lubbock | authorlink = | title = Storytelling in Christian Art from Giotto to Donatello | edition = | publisher = Yale University Press | location = New Haven, London | year = 2006 | page= 215 | isbn = 0-300-11727-2 | url = }}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Brancacci, Felice}} [[Category:14th-century births]] [[Category:15th-century deaths]] [[Category:Year of birth missing]] [[Category:Year of death missing]] [[Category:Italian businesspeople]] [[Category:Ambassadors of the Republic of Florence]] [[Category:15th-century people of the Republic of Florence]]

'''Fira de Barcelona''' is [[Barcelona]]’s [[trade fair]] institution and one of the most important in [[Europe]]. Every year, it organises numerous trade shows and congresses, which bring together leading companies from different economic sectors to showcase their new products, exchange experiences and promote business. ==Information of interest== It hosts over 120 trade shows, congresses and corporate events per year with 30,000 exhibitors, both direct and represented, and receives 2 million visitors from over 200 countries. Its annual economic contribution to the city of Barcelona and its surroundings is estimated at over 2,600 million Euros and also brings added social and public value. Fira de Barcelona works to develop new opportunities for overseas business, especially in Asia and Latin America, geared to increasing the participation of Fira exhibitors in events in other countries, replicating some shows that are held in Barcelona and selling services, technology, management and advice to other organisers and exhibition centres. Fira de Barcelona has established itself as a global events organiser with and international positioning twinned with the unmatchable Barcelona brand, a city with over a century of tradition in the organization of big events. ==History== Barcelona’s trade fair tradition dates back to the [[Exposición Universal of 1888]] and the [[Exposición Internacional of 1929]]. In 1932, Fira Internacional de Barcelona was officially constituted, declared for public use and, in 2000, the [[Generalitat de Catalunya]] was incorporated in the government organs, together with the [[Barcelona City Council]] and the [[Barcelona Chamber of Commerce]]. In 2010, it revised its strategic plan named “new value proposal” in order to anticipate the future demands of the market, based on reinforcing the ranking of its shows, promoting innovation and knowledge and boosting international business. ==Two large venues: Montjuïc and Gran Via== Fira de Barcelona has over 400,000 m2 of exhibition floor space and is one of the largest in Europe, divided into two large venues: the emblematic Montjuïc and the modern [[Gran Via (Barcelona)|Gran Via]], designed by the Japanese architect Toyo Ito. ==Shows== The main shows held in Fira de Barcelona are: [[Mobile World Congress]]; [http://www.alimentaria-bcn.com/en] Alimentaria; [http://www.hispack.com] Hispack; [http://www.ibtmworld.com] ibtm world; [http://www.salonpiscina.com] International Swimming Pool Show; [http://www.hostelco.com] Hostelco, International Catering Equipment Show; [http://www.construmat.com] Barcelona Building Construmat; [http://www.expoquimia.com] Expoquimia, Equiplast and Eurosurfas; [http://www.barcelonabridalweek.com] Barcelona Bridal Fashion Week; [http://www.graphispag.com] Graphispag; [http://www.automobilebarcelona.com] Automobile Barcelona; [http://www.salonnautico.com] Barcelona International Boat Show; [http://www.smartcityexpo.com] Smart City Expo World Congress; [http://www.iotsworldcongress.com] IoT Solucions World Congress Other important events are [http://www.bizbarcelona.com] Bizbarcelona, the show for business owners and entrepreneurs; [http://www.bmpsa.com/] Barcelona Meeting Point; [http://www.silbcn.com] International Logistics Show (SIL); [http://www.b-travel.com] B-Travel; [http://www.ficomic.com] International Comic Show of Barcelona; [http://www.ensenyament.com] Saló de l'Ensenyament; and [http://www.saloncaravaning] Caravanning. == Congresses == Fira de Barcelona hosts numerous congresses and business, social, cultural and institutional events in the facilities of the Montjuïc and Gran Via exhibition centres, where the Palau de Congresos de Barcelona and the Centro de Convenciones are located, respectively. In July 2011, GSM Association, which represents the interests of over 800 mobile phone operators worldwide and over 200 companies in the extensive mobile ecosystem, chose Barcelona as Mobile World Capital for the 2012-2018 period, a title extended until 2023 in July 2015 . [https://mobileworldcapital.com] Barcelona Mobile World Capital is an initiative to turn the city into the permanent world centre of mobile communications, where people, companies and institutions work together to exploit the potential of mobile technologies as an element to transform daily life and create new business opportunities. Promoted by the Spanish Ministry of Industry, Energy and Tourism, the Catalan Generalitat, the Barcelona City Council and GSMA, it is based on the MWHub and MWCongress, concerned with industrial and business development, MWCentre and MWFestival that impact people and their social life. Among other important events, Fira hosted the World Cardiology Congress in 2006 and the European Cardiology Congress in 1999 and 2009, organised by the European Society of Cardiology; the 14th World AIDS in 2002, organised by the International AIDS Society; The International Rotary Club Convention in 2002, organised by Rotary International; the United Nations meeting on Climate Change in 2009 and ITMA, the world's largest international textile machinery exhibition held in 2011. == Public transport == '''Fira Montjuïc'''
Metro: Lines [[Barcelona Metro line 1|L1]], [[Barcelona Metro Line 3|L3]] and [[Barcelona metro line 8|L8]] [[Plaça d'Espanya station|Espanya]] Station.
Bus: Lines D20, H12, V7, 9, 13, 27, 37, 50, 65, 79, 91, 109, 150 and 165
Train: RENFE [[Barcelona Sants railway station|Barcelona Sants]] Station (500m) and [[Ferrocarrils de la Generalitat de Catalunya|FGC]] [[Plaça d'Espanya station]], Lines: S8, S33, R6, R5 and S4 '''Fira Gran Vía'''
Metro: Line [[Barcelona metro line 9|L9]], [[Fira (Barcelona Metro)|Fira]] station or lines [[Barcelona metro line 8|L8]] and [[Barcelona metro line 9|L9]] [[Europa-Fira (Barcelona Metro)|Europa-Fira]] station.
Bus: Line 79 links Gran Via to Montjuïc and other areas of the city.
Train: Lines S8, S33, R6, R5 and S4. [[Ferrocarrils de la Generalitat de Catalunya]] (FGC).
Direct service between [[Plaça d'Espanya station|Plaça Espanya]] (Montjuïc Exhibition Centre) and [[Europa – Fira station|Europa-Fira]] (Gran Via Exhibition Centre) stations. == External links == {{commons category}} * [http://www.firabarcelona.com/ Fira de Barcelona] {{en icon}} {{ca icon}} {{es icon}} {{coord|41|22|27|N|02|09|04|E|type:landmark_region:ES-CT|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fira De Barcelona}} [[Category:Trade fairs in Spain]] [[Category:Convention centers in Catalonia]] [[Category:Companies based in Barcelona]] [[Category:Economy of Catalonia]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Barcelona]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Barcelona]] [[Category:1932 establishments in Spain]]

revision.text:
'''Fleet management software''' (FMS) is [[computer software]] that enables people to accomplish a series of specific tasks in the management of any or all aspects relating to a fleet of [[vehicles]] operated by a company, government, or other organisation. These specific tasks encompass all operations from vehicle acquisition through maintenance to disposal.<ref>{{cite book|last=Bennett|first=Sean|title=Heavy Duty Truck Systems|edition=5|date=February 2, 2010|publisher=Delmar Cengage Learning|isbn=978-1435483828|pages=116–117}}</ref>
==Fleet management software functions==
The main function of [[fleet management]] software is to gather, store, process, monitor, report on and export information. Information can be imported from external sources such as [[gas pump]] processors, territorial authorities for managing vehicle registration (for example [[DVLA]] and [[VOSA]]), financial institutions, insurance databases, vehicle specification databases, mapping systems and from internal sources such as [[Human Resources]] and [[Finance]].
===Vehicle management===
Fleet management software should be able to manage processes, tasks and events related to all kinds of vehicles - car, [[truck]]s, earth-moving machinery, buses, forklift trucks, trailers and specialist equipment, including:<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.drivingtests.co.nz/resources/fleet-management-software-functions/|title=Fleet Management Software Functions|work=DT Driver Training Resources}}</ref>
* Vehicle inventory - the number and type of vehicles * Vehicle maintenance - specific [[Planned maintenance|routine maintenance]] and scheduled maintenance, and ad hoc requirements * Licensing, registration, [[MOT test|MOT]] and [[tax]] * [[Vehicle insurance]] including due dates and restrictions * [[Cost management]] and analysis * Vehicle disposal
===Driver management=== * [[Driver license]] management, including special provisions * Logging of penalty points and infringements against a licence * Booking system for pool vehicles
===Incident management=== * Accidents and fines, plus apportioning costs to drivers
===Tracking=== * [[Telematics]] * [[Route planning]] * Logbooks and work time * Alerts
==Software procurement and development==
Fleet management software can be developed in-house by the company or organisation using it, or be purchased from a third party. It varies greatly in its complexity and cost.
Fleet management software is directly related to [[fleet management]]. It originated on mainframe computers in the 1970s and shifted to the [[personal computer]]s in the 1980s when it became practical. In later years however Fleet Management Software has been more efficiently provided as [[SaaS]]. Fleet management software has become increasingly necessary and complex as increasing amounts of [[vehicle]] related [[legislation]] has been brought in.
==See also== [[Vehicle tracking]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Business software]] [[Category:Transportation planning]] [[Category:Automotive software]] [[Category:Fleet management]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Frederick Anderson | image = Frederick Anderson, Chairman of the Shanghai Municipal Council.jpg | fullname = | birth_date = {{birth date|1855|11|17|df=y}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{death date and age|1940|1|5|1855|11|17|df=y}} | death_place = | height = | position = [[Forward (association football)|Forward]] | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = | years1 = –1872 | years2 = 1872–1873 | years3 = 1873– | clubs1 = [[Clydesdale F.C.|Clydesdale]] | clubs2 = [[Queen's Park F.C.|Queen's Park]] | clubs3 = [[Clydesdale F.C.|Clydesdale]] | caps1 = 0 <ref group = "note" name ="sfl">The [[Scottish Football League]] did not commence play until the 1890–91 season.</ref> | caps2 = 0 <ref group = "note" name ="sfl"/> | caps3 = 0 <ref group = "note" name ="sfl"/> | goals1 = 0 | goals2 = 0 | goals3 = 0 | manageryears1 = | managerclubs1 = | nationalyears1 = 1874 | nationalteam1 = [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]] | nationalcaps1 = 1 | nationalgoals1 = 1 }} {{Infobox officeholder |name = |image = |imagesize = |caption = |order = [[Shanghai Municipal Council#List of Chairmen of the Shanghai Municipal Council|Chairman of the Shanghai Municipal Council]] |term_start = 1899 |term_end = 1900 |predecessor = [[James Fearon (businessman)|James S. Fearon]] |successor = [[E. A. Hewett]] |term_start2 = 1904 |term_end2 = 1906 |predecessor2 = [[William George Bayne]] |successor2 = [[Cecil Holliday]] |birth_date = |birth_place = |death_date = |death_place = |constituency = |party = |spouse = |profession = |religion = |signature = |footnotes = }} '''Frederick Anderson''' (1855–1940) was a [[Scottish people|Scottish]] [[association football|football]] player and businessman in Shanghai and London. He served two terms as the Chairman of the [[Shanghai Municipal Council]].
==Life and career== Anderson was born on 17 November 1855 in Scotland, to James Anderson.<ref>Who's Who in the Far East 1906; British Peerage</ref> He was educated at [[The Glasgow Academy]].
Anderson played as a [[forward (association football)|forward]] for [[Clydesdale F.C.|Clydesdale]], [[Queen's Park F.C.|Queen's Park]] and represented the [[Scotland national football team|Scotland]] national team once, in an 1874 [[friendly match]] against [[England national football team|England]]. He scored Scotland's first goal in a 2–1 win.<ref>[http://www.scottishfa.co.uk/international_fixture_details.cfm?page=1921&matchid=58025 Scottish Football Association]</ref><ref>[http://www.londonhearts.com/scotland/games/18740307.html Sat 07 Mar 1874 Scotland 2 England 1], London Hearts.</ref> He also played in the first ever [[Scottish Cup Final]], which his Clydesdale team lost 2–0 to his former club, Queen's Park in 1874.
Anderson moved to Shanghai in the early 1880s to join Messrs Holliday, Wise & Co.. At the beginning of 1890 he joined Messrs Ilbert & Co and by 1909 had become the principal partner of the firm.<ref>North China Herald, May 15, 1909, p402</ref>
Anderson served on the [[Shanghai Municipal Council]] for eight years from 1892 to 1897. The Municipal Council was the body that ran the Settlement. He was elected Chairman in August 1899 following the resignation of [[James Fearon (businessman)|James Fearon]] and served until 1900. He served as Chairman again from 1904 to 1906. He was also the local chairman in Shanghai of the [[China Association]].
In 1898-99 and 1908-9, Shanghai Rugby Club chose Frederick Anderson as President in 1905.<ref>North China Herald, 3 November 1905 and North China Herald, May 15, 1909, p402</ref> He had previously played two games of rugby for the second Shanghai Football Club, once in January 1882 and then four years later in January 1886.
He left Shanghai in 1909 and returned to London.<ref>North China Herald, May 15, 1909, p378 and 402</ref> In 1919, was serving as the chairman of the [[China Association]] in London<ref>Canton Times, Feb 4, 1919, p6</ref> and in 1922, he was re-elected President of the association.<ref>North China Herald, 16 Sept 1922, p801</ref>
He died on 5 January 1940.<ref>Burke's Peerage and Baronetage, 106th edition vol 1 p181 by Charles Mosley (1999) There is what is reported to be a gravestone of Anderson at the Soong Ching-ling Memorial Park in Shanghai. [https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/114290732 Find a Grave Memorial]. This is most likely not Anderson's grave. He does not appear to have died in Shanghai.</ref>
==Personal life== Anderson married Sophia Louisa Le Hunte Ward, daughter of [http://www.pdavis.nl/ShowBiog.php?id=1428 Admiral T. Le Hunte Ward C.B.] on 4 June 1896. They had two children Frederick Le Hunte Anderson, and Helen Sophia Anderson.<ref>Who's Who in the Far East 1906; British Peerage</ref>
==Further reading== *[http://www.treatyportsport.com/person-14---frederick-anderson.html Profile of Anderson from Treaty Port Sports]
==Notes== <references group="note" />
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{SFA profile}} *[http://www.londonhearts.com/scotland/players/frederickanderson.html London Hearts profile]

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2013}} {{Infobox company | name = Improvision | logo = | type = Public | parent = [[PerkinElmer]] | foundation = 1990 | location = [[Coventry]], [[England]] | industry = [[Life Sciences]] | products = [[Digital imaging|Imaging]], [[Software]], [[Microscopy]] | homepage = [http://www.improvision.com/ www.improvision.com] }} '''Improvision''' is a software developer based in [[Coventry]], [[England]]. The company is the developer of Confocal, live cell imaging solutions and image analysis software for 2D, 3D and 4D imaging.
Improvision was founded in 1990 by Ken Salisbury, Andrew Waterfall and John Zeidler. Improvision was acquired by [[PerkinElmer]] on 2 April 2007, in a cash transaction.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://phx.corporate-ir.net/phoenix.zhtml?c=209667&p=irol-newsArticle&ID=980803&highlight=#top | title = PerkinElmer Acquires Improvision Ltd | publisher = PerkinElmer Corporate News}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Matt |last=Wilkinson |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=PerkinElmer buys imaging software specialist. PerkinElmer have continued to expand their cellular imaging portfolio with the acquisition of software company Improvision. |url=http://www.in-pharmatechnologist.com/news/ng.asp?id=75523 |work= in-PharmaTechnologist.com|publisher= |date= 5 April 2007 |accessdate=3 July 2008 }}</ref>
The company is based in Coventry, England, and it develops and sells scientific imaging equipment and software including [[confocal microscopy| confocal microscopy systems]] and image analysis software ([http://www.improvision.com/products/volocity Volocity]) for the [[Life Sciences]] industry.<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title= Imaging cells in four dimensions: Improvision's Volocity lets researchers examine how 3D images change over time. |url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-32562_ITM |work=The Scientist |publisher= |date=18 February 2002 |accessdate=3 July 2008 }}</ref>
In 2004, Improvision was runner-up in the [[Apple Design Awards#2004 Winners|Apple Design Awards]] for Best Mac OS X Scientific Computing Solution for their Volocity 2.6.1 software release. In 2002, it was a winner in the annual Lord Stafford Awards for Innovation.<ref>{{cite news |first=Steve |last=Pain |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Improvision wins prestige award for innovation |url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-26216111_ITM |work= The Birmingham Post|publisher= |date=9 October 2002 |accessdate=3 July 2008 }}</ref>
In April 2000, Improvision received a [[Queen's Award for Enterprise]], the highest honour which can be given to a UK company, in recognition of outstanding achievement in export sales.<ref>{{cite news|first=Peter |last=Dunn |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=National Award for University Support that Helped Coventry Company Achieve 700% Increase in Sales |url=http://www.warwick.ac.uk/news/pr/science/402 |work=The University Of Warwick |publisher= |date= |accessdate=4 July 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050526230406/http://warwick.ac.uk/news/pr/science/402 |archivedate=26 May 2005 }}</ref>
==References==
{{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.improvision.com/ Improvision] * [http://www.perkinelmer.com PerkinElmer Corporate website] * [http://las.perkinelmer.com Life and Analytical Sciences website]

{{Use Australian English|date=March 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2016}} {{Infobox MP |honorific-prefix = |name = James Dimmitt |honorific-suffix = |image = |image_size = |office = Member of the [[Western Australian Legislative Council|Legislative Council]]
of [[Western Australia]] |constituency = [[Metropolitan-Suburban Province|Metropolitan-Suburban]] |term_start = 22 May 1938 |term_end = 13 April 1953 |predecessor = [[Alec Clydesdale]] |successor = [[Arthur Griffith (Australian politician)|Arthur Griffith]] |birth_date = {{Birth date|1888|6|21|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Richmond, Victoria|Richmond]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], Australia |death_date = {{Death date and age|1957|1|29|1888|6|21|df=yes}} |death_place = [[London]], England |party = [[Liberal Party of Australia (Western Australian Division)|Liberal]] |alma_mater = }} '''James Albert Dimmitt''' (21 June 1888 – 29 January 1957) was an Australian politician who was a [[Liberal Party of Australia (Western Australian Division)|Liberal Party]] member of the [[Western Australian Legislative Council|Legislative Council]] of [[Western Australia]] from 1938 to 1953. He later served as [[Agent-General for Western Australia]] from 1953 until his death. Dimmitt was born in [[Melbourne]], and arrived in Western Australia in 1911, where he began working as a salesman. He eventually became a company director, serving on the boards of a wide variety of companies, including a [[match]] company, an insurance company, a coal-mining firm, and an airline ([[West Australian Airways]]). His own company, Armstrong Dimmitt Ltd., sold motor vehicle parts and accessories. Dimmitt was elected to parliament in 1938, representing [[Metropolitan-Suburban Province]]. He was appointed chairman of committees in the Legislative Council in 1946, replacing [[James Cornell]]. In 1953, the Liberal government of [[Ross McLarty]] appointed Dimmitt to the position of agent-general (the government's representative in London), which meant he had to resign from parliament. He served until his death in January 1957.[http://www.parliament.wa.gov.au/parliament/library/MPHistoricalData.nsf/(Lookup)/D184A64E8E0F8C5F482577E50028A5B8?OpenDocument James Albert Dimmitt] – Biographical Register of Members of the Parliament of Western Australia. Retrieved 23 May 2016. ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dimmitt, James}} [[Category:1888 births]] [[Category:1957 deaths]] [[Category:Agents-General for Western Australia]] [[Category:Australian businesspeople]] [[Category:Liberal Party of Australia members of the Parliament of Western Australia]] [[Category:Members of the Western Australian Legislative Council]] [[Category:People from Melbourne]] [[Category:20th-century Australian politicians]]

[[Image:Jan Cock Blomhoff 1.jpg|thumb|Jan Cock Blomhoff, director ("opperhoofd") of Dejima, the Dutch trading colony in the harbour of Nagasaki, Japan, with his little son Johannes in the arms of Petronella Muns, a Dutch nurse-maid (anonymous Japanese artist).]] [[Image:BlomhoffJapan.jpg|thumb|Jan Cock Blomhoff and his red-haired wife [[Titia Bergsma]] (seated), their infant son Jantje, the wetnurse [[Petronella Muns]](standing), the [[Indonesians|Indonesian]] maid Marathy, and a [[Javanese people|Javanese]] servant boy (behind sofa). [[Japan]]ese print drawn by [[Kawahara Keiga]], circa 1817.]]
'''Jan Cock Blomhoff''' ([[Amsterdam]], 5 August 1779 – [[Amersfoort]], 15 August 1853) was director ("[[opperhoofd]]") of [[Dejima]], the Dutch trading colony in the harbour of [[Nagasaki, Nagasaki|Nagasaki]], [[Japan]], 1817–1824,<ref>Historiographical Institute. (1988). ''Historical documents relating to Japan in foreign countries,'' Vol. I, p. 65.</ref> succeeding [[Hendrik Doeff]].
During his first stay on the island (1809–1813) he had an affair with a Japanese woman and the couple had a child, who died in 1813.
When he arrived in Dejima for the second time in August 1817 he was accompanied by his wife [[Titia Bergsma]], whom he had married in 1815; his son Johannes; [[Petronella Muns]], a Dutch wetnurse; and an Indonesian maid. The ladies and the little boy were not allowed to stay. In the short time they stayed there, till December 1817, they were often drawn by artists, who had never seen other than Japanese women, and 500 different prints widely circulated throughout the country.
Blomhoff is commemorated in the [[Specific name (zoology)|specific name]] of an Asiatic pit viper, ''[[Gloydius blomhoffii]]''.<ref>Beolens, Bo; Watkins, Michael; Grayson, Michael (2011). ''The Eponym Dictionary of Reptiles''. Baltimore: Johns Hopkins University Press. xiii + 296 pp. {{ISBN|978-1-4214-0135-5}}. ("Blomhoff", p. 28).</ref>
==See also== *[[Dutch East India Company]] *[[VOC Opperhoofden in Japan]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== *Effert, Rudy. (2008). [https://books.google.com/books?id=0hSLWs5GG4UC&dq=jan+cock+blomhoff&source=gbs_navlinks_s ''Royal Cabinets and Auxiliary Branches.''] Leiden: Research School CNWS. {{ISBN|9789057891595}}; [http://www.worldcat.org/title/royal-cabinets-and-auxiliary-branches-origins-of-the-national-museum-of-ethnology-1816-1883/oclc/244247206 OCLC 244247206] *{{nihongo|Historiographical Institute, the University of Tokyo|東京大学史料編纂所|Tokyo daigaku shiryō hensan-jo''}}. (1963). ''Historical documents relating to Japan in foreign countries: an inventory of microfilm acquisitions in the library of the Historiographical Institute, the University of Tokyo.'' [http://www.worldcat.org/title/historical-documents-relating-to-japan-in-foreign-countries-an-inventory-of-microfilm-acquisitions-in-the-library-of-the-historiographical-institute-shiryo-hensan-jo-the-university-of-tokyo/oclc/450710 OCLC 450710]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Blomhoff, Jan Cock}} [[Category:1779 births]] [[Category:1853 deaths]] [[Category:Dutch businesspeople]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Amsterdam]] [[Category:Dutch chiefs of factory in Japan]]

[[File:Joh Bailey.jpg|thumbnail|Joh Bailey in January 2012]] '''Joh Bailey''' is a leading [[Australia]]n [[Haircut|hair stylist]] based in [[Sydney]]. His career has spanned 40 years and he has had considerable success, with high-profile clientele and a chain of self-branded salons.
== Achievements == Bailey has rendered his services to well-known people, including [[Elle Macpherson]], [[Linda Evangelista]], [[Olivia Newton-John]], [[Kerri-Anne Kennerley]], [[Kylie Minogue]] and [[Judy Davis]]. In 1997, he worked with [[Diana, Princess of Wales]]. He is also known for working with his business partner, Marilyn Koch.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Sydney Morning Herald|url=http://www.smh.com.au/lifestyle/private-sydney/ps-joh-bailey-crowning-glory-20151112-gkx5sj.html|accessdate=26 January 2017}}</ref>
Joh Bailey's work has appeared on covers of publications such as ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue Australia]]'', ''[[Harper's Bazaar]]'', ''[[ELLE]]'' and ''[[Marie Claire]]''. In addition, he has worked with clients such as [[Giorgio Armani]], [[Louis Vuitton]], [[Gucci]] and [[Escada]] in preparing fashion shows.
For the [[2000 Olympics|Sydney 2000 Olympic Games]], he was named official hair stylist for the opening and closing ceremonies. He was a spokesperson for haircare brand Sunsilk and has participated in its television campaign. In 2004, he received the Master Hairdressers Award.
== Business Achievements == In 1985, the first Joh Bailey hair salon was opened at [[Double Bay, New South Wales|Double Bay]]. Salons were then opened in the Sydney CBD, Bowral, South Yarra in Melbourne, and Bondi Junction.<ref>[http://www.johbailey.com.au/locations.html Joh Bailey<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070509082609/http://www.johbailey.com.au/locations.html |date=2007-05-09 }}</ref> In 2006 Joh, working with Bush Australia (a division of UK electronics company AlbaPlc), launched his own brand of haircare appliances.<ref>http://www.johbailey.net.au {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120320231033/http://www.johbailey.net.au/ |date=2012-03-20 }}</ref>
== Other facts == Joh Bailey has supported charities such as Guide Dogs NSW/ACT, Fashion for AIDS, The Australian Variety Club, The Victor Chang Cardiac Research Institute, Wishlist(Sunshine Coast Health Foundation)and Fashion Supports Breast Cancer.
He is an ex-student of [[James Ruse Agricultural High School]] in [[Sydney]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.news.com.au/dailytelegraph/story/0,22049,24926564-5001021,00.html| title=The school where every kid's a genius| publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]] | date=2009-01-18 | accessdate=2009-04-23}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links==

revision.comment: Rescuing 0 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v1.3beta8)
revision.text:
'''John''' Mikael Holtz '''Elvesjö''', born September 19, 1977, is a Swedish entrepreneur and inventor. Born Holtz, John Elvesjö took his mother’s maiden name at the age of 18 when his father died.
Elvesjö studied [[Engineering Physics]] at the [[Royal Institute of Technology]] in [[Stockholm]]. He founded his first company in 1999, Jenser Technology, which was a spin-off from the Institute of Surface Chemistry and based on his previous research there.
In 1995 Elvesjö was recruited by Henrik Eskilsson as the first employee of Trampolinspecialisten. Elvesjö, Henrik Eskilsson and Marten Skogö founded a new company in 2001 which was named [[Tobii Technology]].<ref name=Edstroem>Adam Edström, [http://www.etn.se/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=46383 "Tobii-John årets IT-förnyare"], ''Elektronik Tidningen'' March 14, 2008 {{sv icon}}</ref> Elvesjö is currently Chief Technical Officer and Executive Vice President at Tobii Technology.
==Scholarships, Grants, Awards and Publications==
* 1998 - 2010 Authored and co-authored 15 or more patents/applications and scientific publications * 2000 Stockholms Stads Uppfinnarstipendium – First prize * 2001 MiljöInnovationsPriset – First Prize with Mårten Skogö for a method of optimizing detergent dosage by measuring surface tension<ref>[http://www.miljoinnovation.se/Material/Files/Pdf/ENG+01.pdf "Winning ideas: The Best Ideas Environmental Innovation 2001] p. 4 (pdf) </ref> * 2002 SKAPA Stipendiet – Grant of SEK 25,000 * 2005 Entrepreneur of the Year Award (ALMI) * 2007 Ranked number three of "up comers 2007" (Sweden's men and women under 40 most likely to influence the future) by ''Shortcut'' magazine<ref>[http://www.tobii.com/all_news/a_fall_of_awards_for_tobii_technology.aspx?profile=17741&menu=17757&submenu=17888 "A Fall of Awards for Tobii Technology,"]{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Tobii Technology Press Release November 22, 2007.</ref> * 2008 Honored as "IT-Renewer of the Year" by ''Chef'' magazine and Teliasonera<ref name=Edstroem/><ref>Elisabeth Vene, [http://www.nyteknik.se/nyheter/karriarartiklar/article267700.ece "Så vinner man kompetenspriser!"] ''NyTeknik'' March 13, 2008 {{sv icon}}</ref>
==References== <References/>
==Sources== * Tomas Zirn, [http://www.idg.se/2.1085/1.263813/idén-foddes-en-kvall-pa-labbet "Idén föddes en kväll på labbet,"] ''Computer Sweden'' October 27, 2009 {{sv icon}} * Tomas Zirn, [http://www.idg.se/2.1085/1.263804/john-elvesjo---med-nasa-for-affarer "John Elvesjö - med näsa för affärer,"] ''Computer Sweden'' October 27, 2009 {{sv icon}} * Klas Andersson, [http://www.e24.se/branscher/internetteknik/artikel_592123.e24 "De gör datorn till en ögontjänare,"] ''[[Svenska Dagbladet]]'' July 22, 2008 {{sv icon}}
==External links== * [http://www.tobii.com Tobii Technology official website] * [http://www.trampolinspecialisten.se Trampolinspecialisten official website ] * [http://www.yki.se/en/Sidor/default.aspx YKI official website YKI] * [http://www.tobii.com/corporate/about_us/awards.aspx Awards received by Tobii] * [http://www.stiftelsenskapa.se/ SKAPA Stipendiet] * [http://www.stockholmbusinessregion.se Stockholm Business Region]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Elvesjo, John}} [[Category:Swedish businesspeople]] [[Category:Royal Institute of Technology alumni]] [[Category:1977 births]] [[Category:Living people]]

{{COI|date=June 2015}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox writer |image =John-jantsch-square.jpg |name = John Jantsch |pseudonym = |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1960|04|02}} |birth_place= |death_date = |death_place= |occupation =Writer, speaker, [[marketer]] |alma_mater = [[University of Kansas]] |genre = Business |movement = |notableworks=''Duct Tape Marketing''
''The Referral Engine''
''[[The Commitment Engine: Making Work Worth It|The Commitment Engine]]'' }} '''John Jantsch''' (born April 2, 1960) is an author, speaker, and [[marketing consultant]] who specializes in assisting small businesses.{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/danschawbel/2012/10/11/is-the-work-you-do-worthwhile/ |title=Is the Work You Do Worthwhile? |author=Schawbel, Dan |work=Forbes |date=October 11, 2012}} He is the author of ''Duct Tape Marketing'', ''The Referral Engine'', and ''[[The Commitment Engine: Making Work Worth It|The Commitment Engine]]''.{{cite news |url=http://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/11/12/this-week-in-small-business-now-what/ |title=This Week in Small Business |author=Marks, Gene |newspaper=New York Times |date=November 12, 2012}} ==Early career== Jantsch grew up in [[Kansas City, Missouri|Kansas City]] and attended the [[University of Kansas]].{{cite web |url=http://www.linkedin.com/in/ducttapemarketing |title=LinkedIn Profile |publisher=LinkedIn}} In 2002, Jantsch created the Duct Tape Marketing System, which trains and licenses small business consultants.{{cite web |url=http://www.ducttapemarketing.com/about |title=Duct Tape Marketing About |publisher=DuctTapeMarketing.com}} Two years later he added the Duct Tape Marketing Consultant Network.{{cite web |url=http://ducttapemarketingconsultant.com/ |title=Duct Tape Marketing Consultant |publisher=DuctTapeMarketingConsultant.com}} Duct Tape Marketing offers marketing workshops and consulting to small businesses looking to expand.{{cite news |url=http://www.businessweek.com/stories/2006-04-26/duct-tape-tips-on-marketing-your-business |title=Duct Tape Tips on Marketing Your Business |newspaper=Bloomberg Businessweek |date=April 26, 2006}} Jantsch suggests treating small business marketing systematically and not creating individual "marketing events."{{cite news |url=http://money.cnn.com/2008/05/21/smallbusiness/customers_sell_for_you.fsb/ |title=Get customers to sell for you |author=Martin, Justin |newspaper=CNN Money |date=May 27, 2008}} One way to do this, Jantsch says, is to maintain a strong and consistent internet presence through blogs, social media, and forums tailored to small business interests.{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB118705175447196673 |title=Getting Effective Publicity for Less |author=Spors, Kelly |newspaper=Wall Street Journal |date=August 14, 2007}} ==Author== ===''Duct Tape Marketing''=== In 2007, Jantsch published ''Duct Tape Marketing: The World's Most Practical Small Business Marketing Guide'', which outlines his systematic approach to marketing.{{cite web |url=https://guykawasaki.com/the_essence_of_/ |title=The Essence of Duct Tape Marketing |author=Kawasaki, Guy |publisher=GuyKawasaki.com |date=April 18, 2007}} The book is divided into three parts.{{cite book|last=Jantsch|first=John|title=Duct Tape Marketing|year=2007|publisher=Thomas Nelson|isbn=1591843111|pages=304|url=https://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/1595554653/jantschcomm-20}} Part I is titled "The Duct Tape Foundation—The Way to Sticky Marketing" and deals with laying the groundwork for a successful marketing system. Part II is titled "The Duct Tape Lead Generation Machine—Turning Stickiness Into a System That Works for You" and it focuses on implementing the strategies of Part I. Part III is titled "Getting on a Roll!" and it serves as a conclusion meant to ground the preceding two parts. [[Michael Gerber (non-fiction writer)|Michael Gerber]] said ''Duct Tape Marketing'' is "just like its namesake – Duct Tape – it's good, incredibly smart, amazingly practical, and immensely sticky stuff."{{cite web |url=http://smallbiztrends.com/2009/01/duct-tape-marketing-book-review.html |title=Duct Tape Marketing: The World’s Most Practical Small Business Marketing Guide – A Book Review |author=Lindeskog, Martin |publisher=SmallBizTrends.com |date=January 4, 2009}} ''Duct Tape Marketing Revised & Updated'' was published in 2011.{{cite web |url=http://www.ducttapemarketing.com/blog/2011/09/27/duct-tape-marketing-updated-revised-and-alive/ |title=Duct Tape Marketing Updated, Revised and Alive |author=Jantsch, John |publisher=DuctTapeMarketing.com |date=September 27, 2011}} ===''The Referral Engine''=== In 2010, Jantsch published ''The Referral Engine: Teaching Your Business to Market Itself''. The book outlines an approach to marketing that moves away from complicated marketing campaigns and instead focuses on personal interactions with customers through outlets such as social media and friend-to-friend word of mouth.{{cite web |url=http://smallbiztrends.com/2010/05/referral-engine-teaching-your-business-market-itself.html |title=The Referral Engine: Teaching Your Business to Market Itself |author=Taylor, Ivana |publisher=SmallBizTrends.com |date=May 8, 2010}} The idea, Jantsch writes, is that a business should always focus on and understand the importance of referrals.{{cite news |url=http://www.entrepreneur.com/blog/218929 |title= Book Review: Referral Engine by John Jantsch |author=Danielson, Diane |newspaper=Entrepreneur |date=October 24, 2010}} ''The Referral Engine'' was a ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' bestseller, a ''Small Business Trends'' "Editor's Choice Best Business Books 2010," ''[[Library Journal]]'''s "Best Marketing Book 2010," and was on 800-CEO-READ's "Best Business Book of 2010" shortlist.{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703957904575252344176187672 |title=Best-Selling Books – Week Ended May 16 |newspaper=Wall Street Journal |date=May 21, 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://smallbiztrends.com/2011/02/best-business-books-2010-editors-choice-winners.html |title=Best Business Books 2010: Editors Choice Winners |author=Taylor, Ivana |publisher=SmallBizTrends.com |date=February 27, 2011}}{{cite news |url=http://www.libraryjournal.com/lj/collectiondevelopmentspecialty2/888437-483/lj_best_business_books_2010.html.csp |title=LJ Best Business Books 2010 |author=Cords, Sarah Statz |newspaper=Library Journal |date=January 6, 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://800ceoread.com/page/show/book_award_winners |title=Book Award Winners |publisher=800CEORead.com}} ===''The Commitment Engine''=== {{Main|The Commitment Engine: Making Work Worth It}} ''The Commitment Engine: Making Work Worth It'' is directed at helping business owners establish lasting commitment in their employees, customers, and businesses and examines what makes some businesses worth referring.{{cite book|last=Jantsch|first=John|title=The Commitment Engine: Making Work Worth It|year=2012|publisher=Portfolio|isbn=1591844878|pages=256|url=http://www.thecommitmentengine.com}}Falls, Jason. [http://www.socialmediaexplorer.com/digital-marketing/how-to-turn-an-authentic-marketing-strategy-into-marketing-action/ How to turn an authentic marketing strategy into marketing action]. Social Media Explorer. October 10, 2012. The book diagnosis the key qualities of successful, "effortless" business approaches.Clayman, Margie. [http://www.chrisbrogan.com/pick-up-the-commitment-engine/ Turning Hatred Into Self Improvement]. Business 2 Community. October 25, 2012. ''The Commitment Engine'' has been featured in ''[[Forbes]]'', [[CNBC]], ''[[The New York Enterprise Report]]'', and was reviewed positively by ''Trust Agents'' author [[Chris Brogan]].Jantsch, John. [https://www.cnbc.com/id/49375627 How Truly Committed Are You to Your Customers?]. CNBC. October 19, 2012.Jantsch, John. [http://www.nyreport.com/culture_hiring_and_management/articles/83465/7_elements_of_a_shared_commitment_culture 7 Elements of a Shared Commitment Culture]. New York Enterprise Report. October 2, 2012.Brogan, Chris. [http://www.chrisbrogan.com/pick-up-the-commitment-engine/ Pick up the Commitment Engine]. Chris Brogan. October 16, 2012. Jantsch has given a [[TEDx]] talk about the book.{{cite web|last=Jantsch|first=John|title=Rethinking Commitment: John Jantsch at TEDxKC|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bXmDaykZobc&list=SPsRNoUx8w3rMviYnw_NlG9g5aNM27SBLT|publisher=YouTube}} ==="SEO for Growth"=== In 2016 John Jantsch and co-author Phil Singleton published SEO for Growth - The Ultimate Guide for Marketers, Web Designers, and Entrepreneurs. The book is aimed at teaching marketers, designers and entrepreneurs the strategic nature of search engine optimization as well as the SEO forces at play in web design and social media. Excerpts from SEO for Growth have appeared in [[Entrepreneur]], [[Copyblogger]], and [[Search Engine Journal]] as well as on [[MSNBC]]. ==Reception== Jantsch's Duct Tape Marketing blog was chosen as a ''[[Forbes]]'' favorite for marketing and small business and his Duct Tape Marketing podcast was called a "must listen" by ''[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]'' magazine.{{cite web |url=http://www.blogtalkradio.com/smartcompaniesthinkingbigger/2012/05/11/john-jantsch--duct-tape-marketing--may-11-2012 |title=John Jantsch – Duct Tape Marketing – May 11, 2012 |publisher=BlogTalkRadio.com |date=May 11, 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://makingworkworthit.com/about/ |title=Making Worth Work It About |publisher=MakingWorkWorhtIt.com}} Jantsch has delivered keynote speeches to organizations such as [[American Express]], [[Microsoft]], [[Verizon]], [[Hewlett-Packard|HP]], and [[eBay]].{{cite web |url=http://www.ducttapemarketing.com/workshops |title=Duct Tape Marketing Workshops |publisher=DuctTapeMarketing.com}} He also is the featured marketing contributor to American Express OPENForum.{{cite web |url=http://www.openforum.com/keywords/john-jantsch-1/ |title=OPEN Forum: John Jantsch |publisher=OpenForum.com}} Jantsch's small business advice has been featured in ''[[New York Times]]'', ''[[Wall St. Journal]]'', and [[CNNMoney]] among others. [[Seth Godin]] called Jantsch the "[[Peter Drucker]] of small business tactics."{{cite web |url= http://sethgodin.typepad.com/seths_blog/2010/01/the-20-media-tour.html |title= The 2.0 media tour |author=Godin, Seth |publisher=Seth Godin's Blog |date=January 26, 2010}} == Bibliography == * ''Duct Tape Marketing'', [[Thomas Nelson (publisher)|Thomas Nelson]]– 2007, 2011 {{ISBN|1591843111}} * ''The Referral Engine'', [[Pearson PLC|Portfolio]]– 2010 {{ISBN|1595554653}} * ''The Commitment Engine'', [[Pearson PLC|Portfolio]]– 2012 {{ISBN|1591844878}} * "Duct Tape Selling", [[Pearson PLC|Portfolio]]– 2014 {{ISBN|1591846331}} * "SEO for Growth", [[SEO for Growth]]– 2016 {{ISBN|0692769447}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.ducttapemarketing.com Official site] *[https://seoforgrowth.com Official book site] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jantsch, John}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American business writers]] [[Category:American business theorists]] [[Category:Business speakers]] [[Category:1960 births]] [[Category:Writers from Kansas City, Missouri]]

page.title: List of companies founded by Stanford University alumni

revision.text:
This is a '''list of companies founded by [[Stanford University]] alumni''', including attendees who enrolled in degree-programs at Stanford but did not eventually graduate. This list is not exhaustive, as it only includes notable [[Company|companies]] <!-- i.e. having articles on Wikipedia, but we don't reference Wikipedia within Wikipedia--> of which the founding and development history is well recorded by reliable sources. In particular, [[Subsidiary|subsidiaries]] are listed with their owners in parentheses.
Stanford University is one of the most successful universities in creating companies, attracting funding, and licensing its inventions to existing companies.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/student/news/the-billionaire-factory-why-stanford-university-produces-so-many-celebrated-web-entrepreneurs-8706573.html|title=The billionaire factory: Why Stanford University produces so many|date=2013-07-12|work=The Independent|access-date=2017-12-22|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newyorker.com/business/currency/stanford-and-its-start-ups|title=Stanford and Its Startups|last=Thompson|first=Nicholas|date=2013-09-11|work=The New Yorker|access-date=2017-12-22|issn=0028-792X}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbinsights.com/research/university-entrepreneurship-report/|title=The University Entrepreneurship Report – Alumni of Top Universities Rake in $12.6 Billion Across 559 Deals|date=2012-10-29|work=CB Insights Research|access-date=2017-12-22|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.graphicsprings.com/founders-funding-and-exit-ranking-usa|title=Founders Funding And Exit Ranking Usa {{!}} GraphicSprings|work=Founders Funding And Exit Ranking Usa {{!}} GraphicSprings|access-date=2018-05-19|language=en}}</ref> It is often held up as a model for [[technology transfer]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.iphandbook.org/handbook/ch17/p13/|title=The Making of a Licensing Legend: Stanford University’s Office of Technology Licensing|website=www.iphandbook.org|access-date=2017-12-22}}</ref><ref>Timothy Lenoir. Inventing the entrepreneurial university: Stanford and the co-evolution of Silicon Valley pp. 88-128 in Building Technology Transfer within Research Universities: An Entrepreneurial Approach Edited by Thomas J. Allen and Rory P. O'Shea. Cambridge University Press, 2014. {{ISBN|9781139046930}}</ref> Stanford's Office of Technology Licensing is responsible for commercializing developments.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://otl.stanford.edu/|title=Office of Technology Licensing {{!}}|website=otl.stanford.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-07-22}}</ref> The university is described as having a strong venture culture in which students are encouraged, and often [[Venture capital|funded]], to launch their own companies.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-startup-stanford-specialreport/special-report-at-stanford-venture-capital-reaches-into-the-dorm-idUSKBN0JO20D20141212|title=Special Report: At Stanford, venture capital reaches into the dorm|last=McBride|first=Sarah|date=December 12, 2014|work=Reuters|accessdate=28 October 2017}}</ref>
According to [[PitchBook Data|PitchBook]], from 2006 to 2017, Stanford produced 1,127 company founders as alumni or current students, more than any other university in the world; and these founders created 957 companies, second only to [[University of California, Berkeley|UC Berkeley]] in the world.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://files.pitchbook.com/website/files/pdf/PitchBook_Universities_Report_2017-2018_Edition.pdf|title=Universities Report: The top 50 universities producing VC-backed entrepreneurs (2017-2018)|last=|first=|date=|website=PitchBook|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://files.pitchbook.com/pdf/PitchBook_Universities_Report_2016-2017_Edition.pdf|title=Universities Report: Top 50 universities producing VC-backed entrepreneurs (2016-2017)|last=|first=|date=|website=PitchBook|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> In addition, according to a Stanford alumni survey conducted in 2011, some 39,900 companies founded by Stanford alumni were active, and companies founded by Stanford alumni altogether generated more than $2.7 [[Trillion (short scale)|trillion]] in annual revenue and had created 5.4 million jobs, roughly equivalent to the 10th-largest economy in the world (2011).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://stanford.app.box.com/s/55estv4w8qi5vgd8n7i8q6jlo7cmdy6f|title=Box|website=stanford.app.box.com|access-date=2018-04-15}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.stanford.edu/news/2012/october/innovation-economic-impact-102412.html|title=Study shows Stanford alumni create nearly $3 trillion in economic impact each year|work=Stanford University|access-date=2017-12-22|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.mercurynews.com/2012/10/24/stanford-alumnis-companies-combined-equal-10th-largest-economy-on-the-planet/|title=Stanford alumni’s companies combined equal 10th largest economy on the planet|date=2012-10-24|work=The Mercury News|access-date=2017-12-22|language=en-US}}</ref>
In this list, founders of a company which [[merged]] with other companies to form a new company are counted as founders of the new company. However, founders of a company which later dissolved into several successor companies are ''not'' counted as founders of those successor companies; this same rule applies to [[Spin-off (corporate)|spin-off companies]]. Finally, a defunct company is a company that had stopped functioning completely (e.g., [[Bankruptcy|bankrupt]]) without dissolving, merging or being [[Acquisitions|acquired]].
== Top companies by revenues ==
=== Fortune Global 500 (2017) === This list shows companies in [[Fortune Global 500]] founded or co-founded by Stanford alumni. The cut-off revenue for 2017 Fortune Global 500 companies is $21,609M in 2016.<ref name=":14" /> {| class="wikitable sortable" ! !Company !Region !Fortune Global 500 (2017)<ref name=":14">{{Cite web|url=http://fortune.com/global500/list/|title=Fortune Global 500 List 2017: See Who Made It|website=Fortune|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-12}}</ref> !Revenue in US$ Millions (2016)<ref name=":14" /> !Type !Category !Year Founded !Comments |-Year Founded |- | href="Alphabet Inc." |1 |[[Alphabet Inc.]] | href="NASDAQ" |[[United States]] |65 |90,272 | href="Conglomerate (company)" |Public |[[Conglomerate (company)|Conglomerate]] |2015 |<ref name="Google" group="Note" /> |- |2 | href="Clarium Capital" |[[Cisco Systems|Cisco Systems, Inc.]] |United States |187 |49,247 |Public |Hardware |1984 | |- |3 | href="Larry Page" |[[HP Inc.]] | href="Sergey Brin" |United States |194 |48,238 |Public |Technology |1939 | |- |4 |[[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] |United States |331 |32,376 | href="Peter Thiel" |Public |Athletic Equipment |1964 | |- |5 |[[TSMC]] |[[Taiwan]] |369 |29,388 |Public |[[Semiconductor]] |1987 | |- |6 | href="Cloudera" |[[Capital One]] |United States |395 |27,519 |Public |[[Finance]] |1988 | |}
=== Fortune 1000 (2017) === This list shows companies in [[Fortune 1000]] (only for companies within the [[United States|U.S.]]) founded or co-founded by Stanford alumni. The cut-off revenue for 2017 Fortune 1000 companies is $1,791M in 2016.<ref name=":182" /> {| class="wikitable sortable" ! !Company !Fortune 1000 (2017)<ref name=":182">{{Cite web|url=http://fortune.com/fortune500/list/|title=Fortune 500 Companies 2017: Who Made the List|website=Fortune|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-11}}</ref> !Revenue in Millions (2016)<ref name=":182" /> !Type !Category !Year Founded !Comments |-Year Founded |- | href="Draper James" |1 |[[Alphabet Inc.]] |27 |90,272 |Public |Conglomerate |2015 | |- |2 |[[HP Inc.]] |61 |48,238 |Public |Technology |1939 | |- |3 |[[Cisco Systems|Cisco Systems, Inc.]] |60 |49,247 |Public |Hardware |1984 | |- |4 |[[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] |88 |32,376 |Public |Athletic Equipment |1964 | |- |5 |[[Capital One]] |100 | href="Peter Thiel" |27,519 |Public |Finance |1988 | |- |6 |[[Gap Inc.]] |178 |15,516 |Public |Clothing/Accessories |1969 | |- |– |[[Trader Joe's]]* |208 |13,300 |Private |[[Grocery store|Grocery]] |1958 |<sup>†</sup> {{small|Equivalently}}<ref name=":122">{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/largest-private-companies/list/|title=America’s Largest Private
