revision.comment: The number of ratified countries changed from 3 to 4, by addition of Cameroon as a ratifier.
revision.text:
{{distinguish|text=the [[Rotterdam convention]]}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox Treaty |name = Rotterdam Rules |long_name = United Nations Convention on Contracts for the International Carriage of Goods Wholly or Partly by Sea |image =RotterdamRulesParties.svg |image_width =275px |caption =Signatories (red) and Ratifications (green) |type = |date_drafted = 11 December 2008 |date_signed = 23 September 2009 |location_signed = Rotterdam and New York |date_effective = (not yet in force) |condition_effective = Ratification by 20 states |date_expiration = |signatories = 25 |ratifiers = 4 (Republic of the Congo, Spain, Togo and Cameroon) |depositor = [[Secretary-General of the United Nations|UN Secretary-General]] |languages = Arabic, Chinese, English, French, Russian and Spanish }} {{Admiralty law}} The "'''Rotterdam Rules'''" (formally, the '''United Nations Convention on Contracts for the International Carriage of Goods Wholly or Partly by Sea''') is a treaty proposing new international rules to revise the legal framework for [[affreightment|maritime affreightment]] and [[Ship transport|carriage of goods by sea]]. The Rules primarily address the legal relationship between carriers and cargo-owners. As of October 2015, the Rules are not yet in force as they have been ratified by only three states.
The aim of the convention is to extend and modernize existing international rules and achieve uniformity of [[International trade law]] in the field of [[admiralty law|maritime]] carriage, updating or replacing many provisions in the [[Hague Rules]], [[Hague-Visby Rules]] and [[Hamburg Rules]].<ref name=un/><ref name=rotterdam>{{cite web|url=http://www.rotterdamrules2009.com/cms/index.php?page=general-information|title=Rotterdam Rules Signature Ceremony|author=Susan Husselman|work=Rotterdam Rules 2009 Secretariat|publisher=Rotterdam Rules 2009|accessdate=16 November 2009 }}</ref> The convention establishes a comprehensive, uniform legal regime governing the rights and obligations of [[Shipment|shippers]], [[Common carrier|carriers]] and [[consignee]]s under a contract for [[door-to-door]] shipments that involve international sea transport.<ref name=un>{{cite web|url=http://www.uncitral.org/uncitral/en/uncitral_texts/transport_goods/2008rotterdam_rules.html|title=2008 – United Nations Convention on Contracts for the International Carriage of Goods Wholly or Partly by Sea – the 'Rotterdam Rules'|work=U.N. Commission on International Trade Law|publisher=UNCITRAL.org|accessdate=16 November 2009}}</ref>
==History== The Hague Rules of 1924 were updated in 1968 to become the Hague-Visby Rules, but the changes were modest. The modified convention still covered only "tackle to tackle" carriage contracts, with no provision for multimodal transport. The industry-changing phenomenon of [[containerization]] was barely acknowledged.<ref>Hague-Visby Rules: Article IV Rule 5c</ref><ref>[http://www.jus.uio.no/lm/sea.carriage.hague.visby.rules.1968/doc.html#31 ''Hague-Visby Rules'']</ref> The 1978 Hamburg Rules were introduced to provide a framework that was both more modern, and less biased in favour of ship operators. Although the Hamburg Rules were readily adopted by developing countries, the new convention was shunned by richer countries who stuck with Hague and Hague-Visby.<ref>[http://www.jacksonparton.com ''The Jackson Parton Miscellany'']</ref> It had been expected that a Hague/Hamburg compromise might arise, but instead the vast (96 articles) Rotterdam Rules appeared.
The final draft of the Rotterdam Rules, which was assembled by the [[United Nations Commission on International Trade Law]], was adopted by the United Nations on 11 December 2008, and a signing ceremony was held in [[Rotterdam]] on 23 September 2009.<ref name=rotterdam/><ref name=rules>{{Citation|title=United Nations Convention on Contracts for the International Carriage of Goods Wholly or Partly by Sea|url=http://www.uncitral.org/pdf/english/texts/transport/rotterdam_rules/09-85608_Ebook.pdf|year=2008|publisher=U.N. Commission for International Trade Law|accessdate=16 November 2009|edition=9|version=9|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110124164131/http://www.uncitral.org/pdf/english/texts/transport/rotterdam_rules/09-85608_Ebook.pdf|archivedate=24 January 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Signatories included the United States, France, Greece, Denmark, Switzerland and the Netherlands; in all, signatures were obtained from countries said to make up 25 percent of world trade by volume.<ref name=dynamic/> Signatures were allowed after the ceremony at the [[Headquarters of the United Nations|U.N. Headquarters]] in New York City, United States.<ref name=rules/>
The [[World Shipping Council]] is a prominent supporter of the Rotterdam Rules. In 2010, the American Bar Association House of Delegates approved a resolution supporting U.S. ratification of the Rotterdam Rules.<ref>[http://www.joc.com/maritime/bar-association-endorses-rotterdam-rules ''Maritime Bar Association Endorses Rotterdam Rules'']</ref><ref>[http://lawprofessors.typepad.com/international_law/2010/09/rotterdam-rules.html ''Law Professors Address International Law'']</ref>
==Main provisions== The following are critical provisions and law changes found in the Rotterdam Rules: * The Rules apply only if the carriage includes a sea leg; other multimodal carriage contracts which have no sea leg are outside of the scope of the Rules. * It extends the period that carriers are responsible for goods, to cover the time between the point where the goods are received to the point where the goods are delivered.<ref name=dynamic>{{cite news|title=UN shipping convention ready for Australia|author=Adeline Teoh|newspaper=Dynamic Export|date=16 November 2009|url=http://www.dynamicexport.com.au/news/un-shipping-convention-ready-for-australia00799/}}</ref> * It allows for more [[e-commerce]] and approves more forms of electronic documentation.<ref name=dynamic/> * It increases the limit liability of carriers to 875 units of account per shipping unit or three units of account per kilogram of gross weight.<ref name=dynamic/> * It eliminates the "nautical fault defence" which had protected carriers and crew from liability for [[negligent]] ship management and navigation.<ref name=dynamic/> * It extends the time that legal claims can be filed to two years following the day the goods were delivered or should have been delivered.<ref name=dynamic/> * It allows parties to so-called "Volume Contracts" to [[opt-out]] of some liability rules set in the convention.<ref name=dynamic/> * It obliges carriers to keep ships seaworthy and properly crewed throughout the voyage.<ref name=dynamic/> The standard of care is not "strict", but "due diligence" (as with the Hague Rules).
==Entry into force and ratifications== The Rotterdam Rules will enter into effect a year after 20 countries have ratified that treaty.<ref name="uncitral.org">[http://www.uncitral.org/uncitral/en/uncitral_texts/transport_goods/rotterdam_status.html ''U.N. Transport Treaty'']</ref> As of 9 August 2011, there were 24 signatories to the treaty.<ref name="uncitral.org"/> The most recent country to sign the treaty was Sweden, which signed on 20 July 2011.<ref name="uncitral.org"/> Spain was the first country to ratify the convention in January 2011.<ref>[http://www.unis.unvienna.org/unis/pressrels/2011/unisl149.html ''U.N. Press Release 2011'']</ref> An overview of signatures and ratifications is shown below:
Upon entry into force of the convention for a country, it should denounce the conventions governing the [[Hague-Visby Rules]] as well as the [[Hamburg Rules]] as the convention does not come into effect without such denouncements.
{| class="wikitable sortable" style="width: 45em; text-align: left;" |+ style="font-size: larger;" | |- ! Country ! Signature ! Ratification |- |{{Flagu|Armenia}} | 29 September 2009 | |- |{{Flagu|Cameroon}} | 29 September 2009 | 11 October 2017 |- | {{Flagu|Congo}} | 23 September 2009 | 28 January 2014 |- | {{Flagu|Democratic Republic of the Congo}} | 23 September 2010 | |- | {{Flagu|Denmark}} | 23 September 2009 | |- | {{Flagu|France}} | 23 September 2009 | |- | {{Flagu|Gabon}} | 23 September 2009 | |- | {{Flagu|Ghana}} | 23 September 2009 | |- | {{Flagu|Greece}} | 23 September 2009 | |- | {{Flagu|Guinea}} | 23 September 2009 | |- | {{Flagu|Guinea-Bissau}} | 24 September 2013 | |- | {{Flagu|Luxembourg}} | 31 August 2010 | |- | {{Flagu|Madagascar}} | 25 September 2009 | |- | {{Flagu|Mali}} |26 October 2009 | |- | {{Flagu|Netherlands}} | 23 September 2009 | |- | {{Flagu|Niger}} | 22 October 2009 | |- | {{Flagu|Nigeria}} | 23 September 2009 | |- | {{Flagu|Norway}} | 23 September 2009 | |- | {{Flagu|Poland}} | 23 September 2009 | |- | {{Flagu|Senegal}} | 23 September 2009 | |- | {{Flagu|Spain}} | 23 September 2009 | 19 January 2011 |- | {{Flagu|Sweden}} | 20 July 2011 | |- |{{Flagu|Switzerland}} | 23 September 2009 | |- | {{Flagu|Togo}} | 23 September 2009 | 17 July 2012 |- |{{Flagu|United States}} | 23 September 2009 | |}
==See also== * [[Hague-Visby Rules]] * [[Hamburg Rules]] * [[Seaworthiness (law)]]

page.title: Small and Medium Enterprise Development Agency of Nigeria

revision.text:
{{one source|date=July 2013}}
'''Small and Medium Enterprise Development Agency of Nigeria''' (SMEDAN) director-general is Muhammad Nadada Umar.
== News ==
On February 9, 2013, SMEDAN signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) with Ministry of Industry of Indonesia's Directorate-General of Small and Medium Industries (SMI). The MoU is for cooperation in enterprises development between the two countries and inviting Indonesian investors to [[Nigeria]].<ref name=ref2013021506> {{Cite news | title = Nigeria wants Indonesia to invest | publisher = Investvine.com | date = 2013-02-15 | url= http://investvine.com/nigeria-wants-indonesia-to-invest/ | accessdate =2013-04-03}} </ref>
On the 1st of March, 2018, [[Femi Pedro]] was appointed by President [[Muhammadu Buhari]] as the Chairman, Board of Directors of the Small and Medium Enterprises Development Agency of NIgeria (SMEDAN). <ref>http://www.businessdayonline.com/buhari-appoints-209-board-chairmen/</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Economy of Nigeria]] [[Category:Organizations related to small and medium-sized enterprises]]

{{multiple issues| {{orphan|date=June 2010}} {{More footnotes|date=November 2011}} }}
[[Image:Tony Spaeth (cropped).jpg|thumb|right|Tony Spaeth]]
'''Otto Lucien Anton "Tony" Spaeth', Jr.''' (February 6, 1934 in [[Saint Louis, Missouri]]) is a [[corporate identity]] planner, consultant, critic and teacher.
==Early years== During his childhood, Spaeth's parents took in [[Anthony Bailey (author)|Anthony Bailey]] (then himself a child) as a war refugee; Bailey has since told the story of their shared childhood years in the books ''America, Lost & Found''<ref>Bailey, Anthony C., “America, Lost & Found” [Random House, 1981; Chicago, 2000]</ref> and ''England, First & Last''.<ref>Bailey, Anthony C., “England, First & Last” [Viking, 1985]</ref>
After the Spaeths moved to Manhattan, ‘Tony S’ was schooled at Millbrook and Portsmouth Priory, then majored in architecture at [[Princeton University]]. After Navy service (as a corpsman, 2nd Marine Division) Spaeth learned market research and account management at Foote Cone & Belding (now [[Draftfcb]]), then joined the [[Harvard Business School]] class of 1963.
In 1964, Spaeth was recruited by Lippincott & Margulies (now [[J. B. Lippincott & Co.|Lippincott]]), where “Corporate Identity” was first being thought through as a meaningful professional specialization. From that point on, “identity” became his primary window on marketing and management issues.
==Middle Years== Two decades of diverse marketing work followed, including classic product management (at American Home Foods, on [[Jiffy Pop]] and [[Gulden's]] brands)… the creation of Controlled Brand Marketing Inc., in partnership with industrial designer Robert P. Gersin, to be product managers/designers for supermarket private labels… consultancy on [[N.W. Ayer & Son]]’s marketing services team (including a key role in creation of the [[Absolut Vodka]] brand)… VP Marketing of the [[Levolor]] blinds company… and then marketing direction of several [[Citicorp]] business units.
==Identity Consulting== Spaeth returned to undiluted identity focus in 1985, when he joined the consulting firm Anspach Grossman Portugal (whose partners he had known from Lippincott & Margulies in the 60s) as director of marketing and a consulting principal. His first act was to change the firm’s descriptive tag from “Marketing Communications and Design” to “Identity Consultants,” thus naming the category in which the firm held a leadership position. Clients he served included [[American Express]] and [[Pfizer]]. He also restructured and directed the firm’s naming capability. In 1990, when AGP’s partners had sold the firm to [[WPP Group]], Spaeth established an independent consultancy.
==Tony Spaeth / Identity== From a base in Rye, New York, since 1990 Spaeth has provided identity planning and creative counsel to scores of clients in diverse categories. He is credited with such corporate brands as [[Dow Jones]], [[Eastman Chemical]], [[Celera Genomics]], [[Flowserve]], [[Commonfund]], [[FIRST]] Robotics and [[Outward Bound USA]].
On the Web site ''[http://www.identityworks.com Identityworks.com]'' (no longer online), since 1998 Spaeth has reviewed noteworthy new identities of strategic or creative interest, with appropriate credit to chief executives and designers alike. The site also provides a variety of analytic and planning tools for branding and design students worldwide, and contains ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20091222051538/http://www.identityworks.com/forum/ Identity Forum]'', where a global panel of leading thinkers and practitioners address identity issues.
Since 1992, Spaeth’s annual rebrandings overview article has appeared in [http://www.tcbreview.com The Conference Board Review] magazine, thus providing a record covering nearly two decades (and counting) of significant identity change.
Spaeth also created and, in collaboration with consultant Tom Vanderbauwhede in Antwerp, maintains the [http://www.corporatebrandmatrix.com Corporate Brand Matrix], building a data base of rebranding case histories for students of identity change. The Matrix documents the leadership intentions in noteworthy corporate rebrandings, matched to the rebranding tools used to achieve them.
In addition to serving the identity community, Spaeth is active in alumni public service initiatives, as advisor to Princeton Project 55 and as a founding director of Partners of ’63 of the Harvard Business School, which seeks systemic improvements in America’s public education systems.
==External links== * [http://www.identityworks.com Official site] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20091222051538/http://www.identityworks.com/forum/ Identity Forum] * [http://www.corporatebrandmatrix.com Corporate Brand Matrix] * [http://www.project55.org Princeton Project 55] * [http://www.partners63.org Partners of '63]
==References== <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
